comments.commentBody: Well, Gov. Walker appears every day now, that the "choice" voters were given was: 1) manipulated and 2) the majority of voters chose Sec. Clinton.

The 2016election was 'not a clear' voice for Republicans.  The popular vote was won by the Democrats.  This was a thin line of under 80K votes that enabled the electoral college victory.  And over 90M eligible American voters didn't vote.  Everyone, not just Liberals, should take a more active role in governance.  Yes, protests and showing up. Republicans in office need to work for all people, not only their base.  They need to be held accountable for their obstructionism to Obama for 8 years and the fact that they do not have anything near a mandate.

Well this is the bottom of the pit. Scott Walker. Reading this screed of republican hate speech, because that's what it is, code for more wealth shifting up. Sure keep Justice at the corrupt state level where the southern drawl sends fear into the hearts of thinking people. Come on...when Jeff Sessions speaks I want to hide everything I own, women and children. Especially when he does his creepy Struthers Martin prison warden act. Let us not forget who Scott Walker and Beauregard the Third represents: the reprobates of the Koch Machine.
I'm all for varied opinions but what does Scott Walker offer? Duplicity, ignorance and smirks!

Has the Republican party ever supported a single idea that has withstood the test of time? Let's see: Republicans were against desegregation, intermarriage, social security, Medicare, Medicaid, worker protections and the 40 hour workweek, not to mention women's suffrage and any kind of anti-discrimination for people of color, gender identification and sexual orientation. Let's face it, Scott Walker, everything you stand for has never stood the test of time. History will judge you in the same company as Orville Faustus, George Wallace and the current president.
Well Lincoln did end slavery.

Hypocritical anyone? This guy Walker refused hundreds of millions of dollars from Feds for Medicaid, high speed rails, etc.
Wisconsin gets almost 90 cents back on each dollar it gives to Feds--hardly pennies.
Walker brought a prosperous state to it's knees with his simple minded posture. Lying, distorting and gross exaggeration have become the norm for Republican politicians.

Richard,

Democrats are in trouble in that part of the country. Minnesota's legislature is now Republican in both houses and then there are Wisconsin and Michigan! What does that say about Progressive politics?

On healthcare the primary problem as always is money and control of the money. Health insurance companies are mostly multi-state and can pick and choose the states they insure in. This gives the federal government a national roll in regulating them as the individual states are at a disadvantage. This also raises the question whether like auto insurance health insurance rates should be set based on local experience or controlled from Washington.

This discussion also raises a question about middle class citizens and insurance in general. If you have assets (a business or a home and car) you need health, long term health, dental, life, auto, homeowners, fire, flood, earthquake and tornado insurance for both your personal and business assets.

If you have no assets you can show up at your local ER and demand treatment which someone else pays for.

Does this sound anything like "equal under the law"? Add to that the fact that the middle class also pay taxes to support the "free" programs and you can see why some voters feel ripped off!

I will listen to Republican elected officials when the common man has the same gold plated health insurance plan that they have. These hucksters will repeal the ACA and give "tax credits", amounting to pennies, and will claim budget victory. Then use that "savings" to build an ineffective wall.

Looking at the picture in the NYT I cannot help but note that there are virtually no black faces. So, if a state does not want minorities, medicaid recipients, equal education, etc. go to wisconsin because the people there have spoken. It isn't always about states rights. Sometimes it is about federal laws.

Taking away the rights of the unions is what has led to the dissolution of the middle class. Who is there, now, to protect workers?

Whenever someone trots out the tired, lame comment that protesters are paid by Soros, it signals to me that they're clueless and uninformed.

And where's the evidence? If protesters are getting paid, I'd like to get on that list as I've not yet received a penny!

"States rights" is just like "activist judges". The definition is in the eye of the beholder. Would former Govenor Walker support a state raising its minimum wage to $15 or preventing fracking? I read the entire op-ed and based on his record, it is easy to call Govneror Walker a hypocrite.
Wisconsin is a failed state. They've done it to themselves by voting for Walker. Sad.

"Returning authority to the states will require congressional Republicans to show the courage of their convictions."

Courage? Convictions? So, nothing to worry about, eh?

Wait a minute!  Why not take this concept a step further, to it's logical conclusion: Do not pay taxes to even city governments; keep the money and spend it on yourself!  The ultimate and most democratic solution.

"I personally made the case for returning authority to the states.... This is how our founders envisioned our country"

Well, yes--but they discovered that it didn't work, and abandoned the Articles of Confederation in favor of the Constitution. That is now the law of the land. Your plea to return to the Articles of Confederation is beyond anachronistic.

Wven though it looks like we'll finish the biennium budget with a balance of $427 million, we need to spend how much to improve our failing roads & infrastructure???? There were the big cuts to the education budget, specifically to the University system. What about jobs to grow tax revenue? That's not going to happen if we don't get broad band internet services in rural Wisconsin. Our existing businesses can't compete without it. No wonder some of our rural communities are dying off. You just go ahead and tout us as a model state. We who live here know different.

Our state and federal elected officials, the republican ones anyway, aren't holding community town halls or listening sessions the way they should.They are running scared! Stand strong? More like play hide and seek and do your dirty work in the dark of night, like you did with Act 10.

And how is that drug testing of SNAP and unemployment applicants going? There's little SUNSHINE in Wisconsin anymore. I can't find any statistics on that!!! I wonder why??? Could it be that the state is spending far more to test than they are saving in benefits? You said that people who tested positive would get treatment. How's that going? And how are they and their families surviving while their benefits are denied?

Enjoy being Governor while you can. The resistance is mounting and gearing up for our next gubernatorial election. But, then maybe your opinion piece reflects your continued hopes to become a Trump appointee.
Intimidation means facing your constituents? That sounds more like cowardice. Surely it is more likely realizing that there is more than one point of view.

Walker, like most Republicans, is very selective in his definitions. "Right-to-work" translates as "right of employers to pay less". I don't think he cares at all that America's most successful and prosperous years were when the unions were strongest. The unions allow people of moderate education to get decent jobs and to contribute to the economy. Walker and his Koch backers would like to see America become a society of haves and have-nots, survival of the fittest. Walker so disappoints me that I refuse to call him by anything but his last name. Same with Trump and all the hypocritical "Christian" Republicans. They are a disgrace to our country and an international embarrassment. I hope Trump takes them down with him.

If Walker and the other Republicans think returning power to the states is so great why are they pushing federal legislation that would force every state to set up a school voucher program or lose federal funding? If they want to return power to the people why is every Republican state legislature rushing through laws that would override local laws that they don't like, such as transgender bathroom laws? Why are Republicans supporting legislation to withhold federal funding from cities that don't help them hunt down immigrants? Why are they so eager for the federal government to prohibit firearm bans at local airports? Why are they working on a national "right-to-work" law?

Turns out that Walker and the rest of the Republicans only support "states rights" and devolution when it suits them, such as resisting federal civil rights laws. But they love to use Walker's happy talk about small government to disguise the real centerpiece of their agenda: Tax cuts for the rich, benefit cuts for everybody else, and crippling labor unions.

Your real national agenda is tax cuts for the wealthy, slashing benefits for the poor, gutting regulations that safeguard the environment, multiplying the deficit, and letting Wall Street corruption run unfettered.  Look at what has actually transpired in this administration so far, Republicans! Wake up and recognize the bait and switch. Politicians like Walker have duped you.
It was a joke.  Everyone laughed.  Actually, a very funny one.  New York humor.

Corrected Rachel from Manafort to Maddow in my first posting!

Rachel Maddow has discussed Paul Manafort's deep ties to Russia and the Russian government, but most importantly has raised the question of how Manafort, with absolutely no experience in running elections and no electoral background at all, wound up as Donald Trump's campaign manager.

Another question she raised regarded the background of our new Secretary of Commerce, who as a senior person at Suisse Bank (I may have the name wrong) was forced out and wound up as the head of the Bank of Cyprus with its deep connections to hiding and laundering money for numerous Russian oligarchs. Why pick a guy with deep connections to billionaire Russians as our new Secretary of Commerce?

Questions abound, and now it's time for some clear answers.

It's amazing how, in such a short span of time, anti-fat pitchfork-wielding ignorant mobs have converted into anti-carb pitchfork-wielding ignorant mobs. Not all carbs are bad, just like not all fats are bad. Minimally processed whole grains are healthy food. I'd prefer if schools were serving oatmeal (the "old-fashioned" kind, not instant) with some fruit, but I understand that, even though oats in bulk will be less expensive than this company's cereal, it requires cooking (and people to cook it), and cutting fruit into pieces takes preparation as well, so the end result may cost more. At any rate, this seems like an improvement over Kellogg's, even if it's not the best possible choice.

"Though nothing has emerged publicly indicating anything more sinister"

What on earth is wrong with you guys at the NYT?!?!?! Trump is ON THE RECORD PUBLICLY saying "Russia, if you're listening, I hope you're able to find Hillary Clinton's 30,000 missing emails." I would say that calling on a foreign power to hack your opponent is pretty sinister and should be mentioned in any article about this. Around the same time, the Republican Party changed its platform policy on the Ukraine, which reeks of a quid pro quo. The only questions are whether it can be proved that the Trump campaign privately coordinated strategy with Russia, paid any of the hackers, and/or received any financial assistance from Russia, and what concessions, in return for this, Trump offered Russia, presumably at the expense of the United States. You could start by extending your investigation into the private server contacts between the Trump organization and the Russian bank Alfa.

Honestly I am this close to switching to the Washington Post which unlike you isn't pathetically trying to curry favor with the White House. Sad!

Because North Korea can fairly easily annihilate South Korea's capital, Seoul, with more than 10 million residents, even with conventional weapons, there is no solution to this problem without Chinese participation. Because nuclear weapons and military power have become central to the North Korean regime's frail legitimacy, the only solution to the crisis would be a carefully executed coup that removes the regime from power without triggering a nuclear launch.  Only China has the connections and clout within North Korea to pull that off.  The Chinese have no interest, however, in removing an effective buffer between their territory and the heavy U.S. troop presence in South Korea. The only way to remove this threat to regional and global security, therefore, is to negotiate a Chinese intervention in the North, a mutual guarantee of the security of a neutral and independent South Korea, possibly to be reunited with the North over time coupled with a Chinese withdrawal, and a U.S. withdrawal from the South. Nothing short of this can remove the North's nuclear threat.
See, now Mark in Boston would be a better choice than Tillerson. How long can we survive amateur hour at the white house?

South Korea has developed a force to attack and decapitate the North Korean regime. North Korea cannot be allowed to continue to develop ballistic missiles and nuclear weapons. If the North Korean regime was decapitated and their command and control centers destroyed their army would surrender in exchange for food and warm meals.

http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/south-korea-military-unit-t...

"the heavy U.S. troop presence in South Korea."? Doesn't North Korea have 30 to 40 times more active duty Troops than the US has in South Korea?

But the Chinese military is more than twice the size of the North Korean forces. Seems like the 2.3 million Chinese troops could care less about the 28,500 American soldiers, sailors, airmen and Marines in South Korea, who they outnumber 80 to 1. Why would they even need a buffer?
That assumes these folks have a conscience and they reflect on the consequences of their actions.  I have my doubts.
